results.title: Special treatment: locking up aboriginal children
results.creator_credit: Margaret Anne Smith and Smith Street Films
results.brief_description:
A documentary exploring the incarceration of First Nations youth in the context of the history of the Stolen Generations, the ongoing racist targeting by police, and an institutionally racist justice system.
Features prominent commentators such as Lyall Munro Jnr., Evelyn Crawford and Shane Phillips, as well as criminologist Chris Cunneen.

results.title: In the gutter, no way?
results.creator_credit: Rhoda Roberts and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: Bobby McLeod, Marlene Cummins and Reg King recount their experiences of growing up as First Nations people in a white society that didn’t recognise their history or respect their rights. As recovering alcoholics, they discuss the factors that enabled them to overcome their alcoholism, when, as stigmatised outcasts in their own land, there was no place to turn to.

results.title: G'day: new accents in australian tourism
results.creator_credit: Colin South, Anne Basser and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Changing Australia”.
Tourism is Australia’s largest employer and continues to grow in importance. This program looks at the importance of understanding the cultures our visitors come from and also at the importance of developing foreign language skills for those involved in the tourist industry. We see examples of how Australia can capitalise on the language and cultural skills which already exist within the migrant communities.

results.title: Up for grabs
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Changing Australia”.
The 1980’s were a time of great change in the struggle for First Nations peoples land rights in Australia. This film documents the passing of legislation in the N.S.W. Parliament which took control from the Aboriginal Lands Commission and passed it to local Aboriginal Land Councils. The Act was opposed by many activists, including Paul Coe and The Munros, father and son, but supported by others, such as Pat O’Shane. Focusing on the town of Moree where the Munros live, the program depicts the history of First Nations’ dispossession and struggle to regain lands or be compensated for their loss.

results.title: Mary Durack
results.brief_description: An interview with Australian writer, Mary Durack, and her sister, Elizabeth, recorded in December 1982 in Perth. Mary Durack had never, when growing up, entertained the idea of being a writer and began writing as “a bit of a game”. Her first efforts were published when she was ten. The Duracks lived on cattle stations in the Kimberleys in NW Western Australia. In the interview, Mary Durack recalls the life on the Argyle and Ivanhoe stations and her close relationship with the First Nations peoples living there as well as the influence her father has had on her books “Kings in Grass Castles” and its sequel. Produced in association with the Archival Film Program of the Australia Council.

results.title: Floral tapestry
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Under southern skies”.
Host Sue Henckel rekindles her passion for wildflowers while touring through two parks. She also visits artist and philosopher William Ricketts whose sculptures in the 1930’s expressed his understanding of his First Nation peoples subjects relationship to their environments. She also meets the descendants of the artist’s subjects who as commercial artists in the 90’s continue to express their relationship to the landscape and plant life.

results.title: Triumph of the nomads
results.creator_credit: David Morgan, Douglas Stanley and Nomad Films International
results.brief_description: Ancient Australia is often seen as a land of stagnation and the early Australians were depicted as one of the most primitive peoples on earth. However, this program examines how the long occupation of pre-white-invasion Australia witnessed spectacular changes. Generations of First Nations peoples saw the great rising of the seas which isolated Australia; they saw, and probably influenced, sweeping changes in vegetation and wildlife. First Nations peoples created lifestyles which suited their environments. Narrated by Geoffrey Blainey.

results.title: Eliza Fraser
results.brief_description: A 19th Century seafarer and his wife journey to Australia, where the crew mutinies, and they are captured by the local Badtjala people. The seafarer is killed and his wife has many adventures before returning home. Stars Susannah York, Trevor Howard, Noel Ferrier and John Waters.

results.title: Where the Green Ants Dream
results.creator_credit: Werner Herzog, Lucki Stipetic, Werner Herzog Filmproduktion and Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen
results.brief_description: A desolate stretch of earth somewhere in Australia. The Wororas and the Riratjingus people preserve their ancient legends, songs and laws of creation here. Theirs is a struggle for a culture, myths and laws that are the result of at least 40,000 years of living in the desert. They come into conflict with the laws of modern Australia and the interests of a large company that works to mine uranium in one of their holy places, the place where the Green Ants dream.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Werner Herzog, Lucki Stipetic, Werner Herzog Filmproduktion and Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen
results.description: A desolate stretch of earth somewhere in Australia. Two tribes of First Peoples, the Wororas and the Riratjingus, preserve their ancient legends, songs and laws of creation here. Theirs is a struggle for a culture, stories and laws that are the result of 40,000 years of living in the desert. They come into conflict with the laws of modern Australia and the interests of a large company that works to mine uranium in one of their holy places, the place where the Green Ants dream.
description_for_label: A desolate stretch of earth somewhere in Australia. Two tribes of First Peoples, the Wororas and the Riratjingus, preserve their ancient legends, songs and laws of creation here. Theirs is a struggle for a culture, stories and laws that are the result of 40,000 years of living in the desert. They come into conflict with the laws of modern Australia and the interests of a large company that works to mine uranium in one of their holy places, the place where the Green Ants dream.

results.title: Two Laws
results.brief_description: An innovative film on the Borroloola people’s struggle for the recognition of First Nations law. First Nations people actively collaborated with the filmmakers in determining the form of the film which is in four parts. “Police times” is a dramatic re-enactment of white oppression in the 1930’s. “Welfare times” A re-enactment of life under the welfare system of the 1950’s. In “Struggle for our land” First Nations peoples’ attachment to the land is described and the first hearing of the Borroloola land claim is also re-enacted. “Living with two laws” is concerned with the movement back to traditional land and the setting up of cattle out-stations.
